newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil shrs end modestly up, welcome CMN decision.
newsitem.headline: Brazil shrs end modestly up, welcome CMN decision.

text.p: Brazilian shares ended modestly up in seesaw trade, with investors upbeat about a government decision to allow foreign investors to operate in derivatives markets for hedge, brokers said.
The Bovespa index of the 48 most traded stocks rose 0.28 percent to 10,745 points. Market turnover was higher than usual at 916.3 million reais ($864.4 million).
Brazil's National Monetary Council (CMN) on Thursday authorized foreign investors under Annex Four rules to operate in derivatives markets for hedging transactions.
Traders expect the decision to boost foreign capital inflows into the Brazilian bolsas as foreigners will be able to hedge their operations in the local markets.
Since August 1995, foreign investors had been forbidden to make any transactions in local derivatives markets.
Benchmark Telebras closed up 0.81 percent at 137 reais, while its common stock rose 0.16 percent to 128.50 reais.
Private mining giant CVRD rose 0.4 percent to 24.90 reais, while state oil firm Petrobras fell 0.2 percent, closing at 245 reais.

The power sector index .IEE, comprising the nine most liquid stocks of the electrical industry, closed up 0.38 percent at 2,778 points. as a final debt restructuring deal between Sao Paulo state and the federal government was to be announced later today.
